subj-group.subject: Teaching Students to Write for the Workplace Part 2

title-group.article-title: Using the Teaching Portfolio to Anticipate Programmatic Assessment

author-notes.corresp: Kenneth R. Price, University of Wisconsin–River Falls, River Falls, WI 54022, USA. Email: kenneth.price@uwrf.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2013 by the Association for Business Communication

abstract.p: Portfolios have long been a staple in professional writing courses: both in employment materials assignments and in entire classes that ask students to reflect on their experiential learning. Portfolios may also be used effectively in business communication teaching methods courses. This article details the justification and methodology for having a teaching portfolio as the capstone assignment in a business communication pedagogy course. It also explains how this portfolio may be used to anticipate programmatic assessment and verification of entry-level business communication courses during the accreditation process.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Professional writing relies heavily on experiential learning, which typically gained through internships and co-ops. In courses with an experiential, or components experiential learning component or activities, students are often asked to reflect thoughtfully on their educational experiences in journals or, more commonly, in portfolios (Dubinsky, 2003; Graves & Epstein, 2011; Worley, 2011).

I use a variation of the reflective portfolio Brammer (2011) describes in my graduate business communication teaching methods course. My students create a teaching portfolio, which serves as the capstone assignment for the course. This assignment introduces my graduate students, teaching assistants, and adjunct instructors to business communication theory and practice; allows them to codify their approach to teaching the discipline; and instructs them in teaching business communication within the structure of verifiable, measureable learning goals and outcomes.

sec.title: Composition and Structure of the Teaching Portfolios
sec.p: The structure of these portfolios is the same as the reports and manuals students are often asked to create in a business communication classroom (Rupert & Loudermilk, 2002), namely, 10 to 20 pages of written material that may include manuals, brochures, handbooks, lab reports, proposals, or electronic documents.

I ask that they publish it as a PDF, include transmittal correspondence, and set the pagination according to business report format with front matter numbered with small Roman numerals and body text with Arabic numbers.
Their completed teaching portfolios have the following elements in this order:

list-item.p: Cover
Title page
Table of contents
Sectional fly pages with advance organizers summarizing each section
Preface with a statement of teaching philosophy
Course content guide (CCG)
Annotated, theoretically justified syllabus and course description
Three sample lesson plans (one for each topic) that show step-by-step how they will integrate the topic into the class curriculum
Video podcast supplement of one of the lesson plans
Annotated list of 10 Internet resources for teaching business communication

sec.title: Sectional Fly Pages With Advance Organizers
sec.p: The fly page summaries mirror the advance organizer approach to teaching that promotes the learning and retention of new, difficult, and technical information (Ausubel & Fitzgerald, 1962).

sec.title: Statement of Teaching Philosophy
sec.p: I ask that they speak to our university’s Quality Enhancement Plan, which stresses engaged learning, into their teaching philosophies. I emphasize that our business communication curriculum should encourage our students to blend the theoretical with the practical and thus bridge the college or university to the world of work.
This curriculum allows students to develop the following proficiencies:

list-item.p: Communicate effectively with a variety of audiences
Practice collaborative efforts
Connect the principles covered in the classroom to real-world projects
View their positions within corporate structures
Develop organizational skills in project management
Understand the need for experiential and engaged learning by including community engagement/service-learning assignments and projects in the curriculum
Formulate a responsible, humanistic system of ethics

sec.title: Course Content Guides
sec.p: Instructional goals and outcomes assessment has become increasingly important at universities and colleges (Chrysler & Van Auken, 1999; Mitri, 2003; Salegna & Bantham, 2002; Taylor, 2002). CCGs for business communication courses provide a concise description of each course, its topical areas, instructional goals, and expected outcomes. These standards outline a course’s policies and curricular design and, most important, detail the course’s methods of evaluation and assessment (see Table 1).

caption.p: An Example Course Curriculum Guide for a Business Communication Course.

tr.th: Instructional Goals: These learning goals should be measurable during the evaluation and assessment phases of the class
Expected Outcomes: At the conclusion of the class, students should be able to do the following
Methods of Evaluation: The following exercises and assignments may be used to evaluate students
Methods of Assessment: At the conclusion of the semester, students should be able to describe and apply the following business communication concepts

tr.td: Experience collaborative writing/editing efforts
Work collaboratively on projects
Group assignments and evaluations
Develop workplace literacies within the context of a social perspective: collaboration, ethics, and authorship/ownership
Draft, edit, and revise business correspondence
Compose various types of letters—good news messages, Requests for Proposals, Requests for Information—memoranda, and e-mails
Business correspondence
Understand how to create and evaluate effective business correspondence
Construct print and digital publications that respond to a particular rhetorical situation
• Analyze rhetorical writing situations critically

Semester-long project: an interactive PDF, a coordinated digital media project, an instructional podcast, or a print publication such as a policy and procedure manual, a business or grant proposal, or an employee handbook
Relate the concepts and techniques for creating, evaluating, and editing print and digital information
• Draft, edit, and revise a semester-long project
Identify target audiences and develop audience profiles
Understand and construct user profiles and develop project specifications
Project proposal, including a detailed audience profile, project milestones, and development schedule
Identify and collect data from target populations and stakeholder groups
Learn strategies for planning, analyzing purpose, gathering data, managing resources, drafting, and revising proposals
Identify target populations, and then construct needs analyses for this target audience
A semester-long business or grant proposal
Describe the various stages of development of documents whose purpose is to fund projects; research, draft, evaluate, and revise proposals for persuasiveness
Introduce the theoretical principles of visual language
Describe and apply the theoretical principles of visual language, information architecture, and page design
Layout grids and typographical matrices
Apply the seminal concepts of visual language: Information mapping, alignment, queuing, filtering, and chunking
Be able to search for a job effectively and efficiently
Write effective resumes, cover letters
Resume or professional portfolio
Describe the most appropriate and effective resume type and format, successful online job searches
Integrate theories and techniques for planning, designing, and writing print and electronic business communication documents using publication standards
Write document- or project-specific style guides and style sheets
Editorial style sheets and word lists
Describe the various stages of the production process for electronic and print publications, as well as the purpose and typical components of a style guide
Create digital media that respond to a particular rhetorical situation
Analyze rhetorical writing situations critically; create, edit, and usability test a semester-long project
Semester-long project: an interactive PDF, a coordinated digital media project, or an instructional podcast
Understand and apply the concepts and techniques for creating, evaluating, and editing digital information
Introduce the principles of effective oral communication
Design slides, handouts
Oral presentation in support of an individual or group business communication assignment
Prepare, design, and effectively deliver oral presentations

list-item.p: The Instructional Goals section details what the instructor intends to accomplish in the course, as well as what the instructor expects the students to learn in the course.

The Expected Outcomes section identifies what the student should know and/or be able to do as a result of completing the course. Since the student outcomes must be measurable, the student evaluation methods must be able to assess the accomplishment of the students in each outcome.
The Methods of Evaluation section details the exercises and assignments used to evaluate students.
The Methods of Assessment section provides the business communication concepts that students should be able to describe and apply at the conclusion of the semester.

sec.title: Verification and Validation
sec.p: For a CCG to be a verifiable assessment tool, all instructors of a particular business communication course must strictly adhere to its standards: the learning goals, educational outcomes, and methods of assessment established at the programmatic level by members of the business writing faculty or the program director. My students must adapt their classroom assignments, exercises, and exams to the learning outcomes and objectives listed in the CCG.

To provide evidence of student learning, the business communication course should use a variety of methods of assessment: direct, indirect, quantitative, and qualitative measurements of the instructional goals and educational outcomes.

list-item.p: Direct Measurements: Standardized pretests and posttests, graded assignments directly related to learning outcomes, and examinations.
Indirect Measurements: Self-evaluations, directed reflection, or job placement.

sec.title: Annotated Syllabus and Course Description
sec.p: I ask them to compose and design a three- to five-page annotated course description and syllabus for their business communication course. The assignment specifications dictate that this document includes the following:

list-item.p: Course outline
Learning objectives
Course policies and procedures
Assignment specifications

sec.p: In at least three pages accompanying the syllabus and course description, they must theoretically justify the purpose, scope, organization, and course assignments, as well as show how the course fulfills the instructional goals and learning objectives described in the CCG.

sec.title: Assignment Sheet with Specifications for Each Assignment
sec.p: I ask that they compose a detailed assignment sheet for their course. These assignments should be clearly related to the instructional goals, student outcomes, and methods of evaluation outlined in the CCG:

sec.title: Three Sample Lesson Plans
sec.p: Each sample lesson plan should cover specific goals. I ask that their plans be thorough enough so that another instructor could teach the class in their absence. To receive full credit, each lesson plan must include the following elements, which I suggest they use as headings:

list-item.p: Summary: This element previews what will happen in the lesson.
Materials: This element lists whatever materials are needed to conduct the lesson.

Instructor Input: This element describes what the instructor will do or say at various points during the lesson. This may be lecturing, giving directions, or guiding students through an activity. It provides a general outline of what the instructor will say, rather than word-for-word detail. I prefer they insert “instructor input” wherever it would occur, rather than describing it all in one place.
Guided Practice: This element describes the activities they will do with students, together as a class, one-on-one, or in groups.
Independent Practice: This element describes the activities that students will do independently, either in or outside of class.

Rationale: This element provides a 300- to 350-word statement in which they explain (a) how the various activities in the plan address the specific goals that they have specified and (b) how their plan reflects their teaching philosophy.

sec.p: They may choose from a variety of topics for their lesson plans, but they must justify how the topics they choose will meet the learning objectives and outcomes detailed in the CCG:

list-item.p: Audience Analysis
Professional Writing Style
Grammar and Punctuation
Language/Concision
Page Layout and Design
Correspondence: Memoranda, Letters, E-mail
Sales Letters
Requests for Proposal
Requests for Information
Negative News Letters
Persuasive Letters
Cross-Cultural Business Communication
Business Presentations
Resumes, Cover Letters, Portfolios
Proposals
Business Reports: Policy and Procedure Manuals, Feasibility/Recommendation Reports, Progress/Status Reports, Employee Handbooks

sec.title: Podcast Lesson Supplement
sec.p: Because research has shown that students may need alternative teaching styles to traditional classroom instruction and that multimodal instruction can markedly improve learning outcomes (Schilling, 2009; Vigentini, 2009), I ask my students to create a 10- to 15-minute video podcast to supplement one of their lesson plans. They can then post these podcasts to Blackboard, our course delivery program, for students to download and view at their own pace.

sec.title: WWW Resources Review
sec.p: For this assignment, they add content to the WWW Resources thread I post on Blackboard. I ask that these sites focus primarily on ideas for teaching a business communication course.

sec.title: Oral Presentation
sec.p: At the conclusion of the semester, they present one of their lesson plans to the class. They share their lesson plans with the other members of the class, which significantly reduces their preparation time for teaching the course.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: A pedagogy course such as this is useful for a number of individuals:

list-item.p: Where there are business communication courses taught by adjunct faculty
Where graduate teaching assistants teach entry-level business writing courses
In small programs or departments with few business communication faculty

sec.p: Along with the obvious benefits for instructors new to the field of business communication, the teaching methods course provides a scaffold for new instructors to codify their educational philosophy, such as teaching within a technological framework, incorporating community engagement and service-learning activities into their classrooms, developing workplace computer literacies, and stressing the importance of experiential learning.
In the reappointment and tenure review process, the pedagogy course provides the basis for integrating teaching and scholarship within the Boyer model of the scholarship of teaching.

disp-quote.p: According to Boyer, the elements that define teaching as a scholarly activity are mastery of the subject being taught, knowledge of pedagogical methods that have been proven effective at promoting learning and skill development, and commitment to continuing personal growth as an educator. (Felder, 2000, p. 144)

sec.p: Finally, in establishing teaching standards, the pedagogy course later provides for instructor-level improvement and establishes a baseline for assessment and measuring programmatic effectiveness during the accreditation process (Cunningham & Omolayole, 1998; Nichols & Nichols, 2000).

fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

bio.title: Bio
bio.p: Kenneth R. Price teaches business and technical communication courses at the University of Wisconsin–River Falls. A graduate faculty member at Missouri State University; California State University, Chico (where he directed the professional writing program); the University of Alaska Anchorage; and Western Carolina University, he was also a documentation consultant to Macromedia.
